values.name: academic painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1487, Pen and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This drawing is based on the "ideal" human-body ratio, as stated in "De architectura." "De architectura" was a treatise by Vitruvius, an architect from the early 1st century BCE.

values.name: academic painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1487, Pen and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This drawing is based on the "ideal" human-body ratio, as stated in "De architectura." "De architectura" was a treatise by Vitruvius, an architect from the early 1st century BCE.

values.name: amazing painting
values.artist: Rembrandt van Rijn, 1642, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This masterpiece, painted by 17th century Dutch artist Rembrandt, depicts a military gathering. At the time, portraits usually showed their subjects standing still. So this was a leap forward in technique. For many years, art scholars thought the painting was set at night, but a restoration revealed a dark varnish. We can now see the dynamic poses and lighting as they were meant to be seen—in the daytime!

values.name: amazing painting
values.artist: Rembrandt van Rijn, 1642, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This masterpiece, painted by 17th century Dutch artist Rembrandt, depicts a military gathering. At the time, portraits usually showed their subjects standing still. So this was a leap forward in technique. For many years, art scholars thought the painting was set at night, but a restoration revealed a dark varnish. We can now see the dynamic poses and lighting as they were meant to be seen—in the daytime!

values.name: ancient statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 1000-400 BCE, Fired pottery
values.museumDescription: A mysterious, riveting doll made from kneaded, unglazed dirt during the Jōmon period. Its large round eyes resemble goggles that intercept light, so its name should come as no surprise. "Shakōki" means "light-intercepting goggles," and a dogū is a small animal figurine.

values.name: ancient statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 1000-400 BCE, Fired pottery
values.museumDescription: A mysterious, riveting doll made from kneaded, unglazed dirt during the Jōmon period. Its large round eyes resemble goggles that intercept light, so its name should come as no surprise. "Shakōki" means "light-intercepting goggles," and a dogū is a small animal figurine.

values.name: basic painting
values.artist: Thomas Gainsborough, 1770, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Gainsborough was known for his innovative use of colors in his traditional portraits, like this one. Although he preferred painting landscapes, his portraits would be the defining work of his career.

values.name: basic painting
values.artist: Thomas Gainsborough, 1770, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Gainsborough was known for his innovative use of colors in his traditional portraits, like this one. Although he preferred painting landscapes, his portraits would be the defining work of his career.

values.name: beautiful statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 130 BCE, Marble
values.museumDescription: A statue of the Roman goddess of love and beauty, Venus was found on the island of Milos. This beautiful sculpture makes many wonder what her original pose might have been.

values.name: beautiful statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 130 BCE, Marble
values.museumDescription: A statue of the Roman goddess of love and beauty, Venus was found on the island of Milos. This beautiful sculpture makes many wonder what her original pose might have been.

values.name: calm painting
values.realArtworkTitle: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
values.artist: Georges Seurat, circa 1885, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Seurat, known as the founder of neo-impressionism, invented the use of brightly colored dots. His method, which does not involve mixing pigments, took time. This piece, for instance, took two years. It shows a crowd enjoying a day off at the river Seine in France.

values.name: common painting
values.artist: Jean-François Millet, 1857, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: The signature piece from Millet, who was known for depicting the lives of commoners in the 19th century.Notice the abundant crops visible in the background relative to the meager wheat remaining for workers.This art served as social commentary in a time of great inequality.

values.name: detailed painting
values.artist: Itō Jakuchū, 18th century, Dyed silk
values.museumDescription: A detailed, colorful, and dynamic piece by Itō Jakuchū, a successful Kyoto artist in the mid-Edo period. High-quality paints on silk help it maintain its brilliant color even now, 200 years after its creation.

values.name: detailed painting
values.artist: Itō Jakuchū, 18th century, Dyed silk
values.museumDescription: A detailed, colorful, and dynamic piece by Itō Jakuchū, a successful Kyoto artist in the mid-Edo period. High-quality paints on silk help it maintain its brilliant color even now, 200 years after its creation.

values.name: dynamic painting
values.realArtworkTitle: Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji The Great Wave off Kanagawa
values.artist: Katsushika Hokusai, circa 1831, Woodblock print
values.museumDescription: The signature piece of ukiyo-e artist Katsushika Hokusai, painted as part of a series when he was in his 60s. Although it is dubbed "Thirty-Six Views," he eventually added 10 more to make 46 in total.

values.name: familiar statue
values.artist: Auguste Rodin, 1902, Bronze
values.museumDescription: This bronze sculpture was crafted by the French sculptor Rodin, known as the father of modern sculpture. The incredibly famous original is located in France. The sculpture was casted over 20 times. As such, authentic pieces can be found all around the world.

values.name: famous painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1503, Oil on poplar
values.museumDescription: The world's most famous smile. It's said that da Vinci kept this painting for himself until the very end...Given its power to beguile visitors all these years later, it's easy to see why.

values.name: famous painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1503, Oil on poplar
values.museumDescription: The world's most famous smile. It's said that da Vinci kept this painting for himself until the very end...Given its power to beguile visitors all these years later, it's easy to see why.

values.name: flowery painting
values.artist: Vincent van Gogh, circa 1888, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Van Gogh painted this piece when he moved to the south of France in search of more vibrant colors. Yellow was Van Gogh's favorite color, and he made seven paintings that featured sunflowers during this time.

values.name: gallant statue
values.artist: Michelangelo, circa 1504, Marble
values.museumDescription: Young David glares at his enemies, sling slung over his shoulder. It took Michelangelo more than three years to sculpt this piece. Close inspection shows heart- shaped eyes, but that's probably meant to depict light hitting them. Hearts didn't have the lovey-dovey symbolism back then that they do today.

values.name: gallant statue
values.artist: Michelangelo, circa 1504, Marble
values.museumDescription: Young David glares at his enemies, sling slung over his shoulder. It took Michelangelo more than three years to sculpt this piece. Close inspection shows heart- shaped eyes, but that's probably meant to depict light hitting them. Hearts didn't have the lovey-dovey symbolism back then that they do today.

values.name: glowing painting
values.artist: Joseph Mallord William Turner, 1839, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: A famous piece by Turner, a "master of light. "It shows an English Navy ship commanded by Admiral Nelson as it's being tugged toward its dismantling.

values.name: graceful painting
values.artist: Hishikawa Moronobu, 17th century, Color on silk
values.museumDescription: A hand-painted piece by Hishikawa Moronobu, an artist known for popularizing the ukiyo-e style. This stirring painting depicts a fashionable woman glancing back over her shoulder.

values.name: graceful painting
values.artist: Hishikawa Moronobu, 17th century, Color on silk
values.museumDescription: A hand-painted piece by Hishikawa Moronobu, an artist known for popularizing the ukiyo-e style. This stirring painting depicts a fashionable woman glancing back over her shoulder.

values.name: great statue
values.artist: Thomas Ridgeway Gould, circa 1883, Bronze
values.museumDescription: A bronze sculpture of King Kamehameha I, who founded the Kingdom of Hawaii in 1810. Traditionally, the sculpture is draped with many leis every year on June 11th.

values.name: informative statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 196 BCE, Granodiorite
values.museumDescription: A stone slab found in Rosetta, Egypt in 1799. Helped efforts to decipher ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs. Almost identical text is written in hieroglyphs at the top, then Demotic script, and lastly Greek script.

values.name: informative statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 196 BCE, Granodiorite
values.museumDescription: A stone slab found in Rosetta, Egypt in 1799. Helped efforts to decipher ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs. Almost identical text is written in hieroglyphs at the top, then Demotic script, and lastly Greek script.

values.name: jolly painting
values.artist: Giuseppe Arcimboldo, circa 1563, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: A curious portrait by Giuseppe Arcimboldo, an Italian painter from the late 16th century. It doesn't take a particularly sharp eye to see that the entire portrait is composed of fresh produce.

values.name: jolly painting
values.artist: Giuseppe Arcimboldo, circa 1563, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: A curious portrait by Giuseppe Arcimboldo, an Italian painter from the late 16th century. It doesn't take a particularly sharp eye to see that the entire portrait is composed of fresh produce.

values.name: moody painting
values.artist: Jean-François Millet, circa 1850, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Millet painted this piece of a farmer sowing wheat seeds in a field after moving to the countryside from Paris. If the piece reminds you of Van Gogh, that's likely because Van Gogh himself was inspired by it!

values.name: motherly statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 5th century BCE, Bronze
values.museumDescription: This wolf from Roman mythology raises a pair of twins, along with some controversy. The original bronze sculpture of the wolf is a masterpiece that dates back to 5th century BCE. The twins were added during the 15th century...or so it was thought.Recent research has given rise to speculation that the original piece may be from the 11th or 12th century. (We will, however, stick with the 5th century BCE estimate for now.)

values.name: motherly statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 5th century BCE, Bronze
values.museumDescription: This wolf from Roman mythology raises a pair of twins, along with some controversy. The original bronze sculpture of the wolf is a masterpiece that dates back to 5th century BCE. The twins were added during the 15th century...or so it was thought.Recent research has given rise to speculation that the original piece may be from the 11th or 12th century. (We will, however, stick with the 5th century BCE estimate for now.)

values.name: moving painting
values.artist: Sandro Botticelli, circa 1485, Tempura on canvas
values.museumDescription: A painting of the Roman goddess Venus riding a scallop shell after being born in the ocean. The name Botticelli is said to actually be a nickname given to the artist's brother, who was built like a barrel. Why this nickname was transferred between siblings is a mystery lost to the ages.

values.name: moving painting
values.artist: Sandro Botticelli, circa 1485, Tempura on canvas
values.museumDescription: A painting of the Roman goddess Venus riding a scallop shell after being born in the ocean. The name Botticelli is said to actually be a nickname given to the artist's brother, who was built like a barrel. Why this nickname was transferred between siblings is a mystery lost to the ages.

values.name: mysterious painting
values.artist: Arnold Böcklin, 1883, Oil on wood
values.museumDescription: A small boat carrying a corpse glides quietly over a still sea to an island of graves surrounded by cliffs. The air of this piece by symbolist painter Böcklin is chilling, but also somehow calm. Böcklin worked here to capture not what he could see, but some of humanity's inner contemplations.

values.name: mystic statue
values.artist: Thutmose, circa 1345 BCE
values.museumDescription: A bust of Nefertiti, whose name means "the beautiful one has come." A "royal wife," she was known as one of the three most beautiful women in ancient Egypt. It is not known whether the left eye is missing because it fell out, or because it was never completed.

values.name: mystic statue
values.artist: Thutmose, circa 1345 BCE
values.museumDescription: A bust of Nefertiti, whose name means "the beautiful one has come." A "royal wife," she was known as one of the three most beautiful women in ancient Egypt. It is not known whether the left eye is missing because it fell out, or because it was never completed.

values.name: nice painting
values.artist: Édouard Manet, 1866, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: One of Manet's earlier works, this painting depicts a young flautist dressed in military uniform. Manet's works are notable for their lack of linear perspective and strong color contrast. These attributes led some to call him "The Father of Impressionism" and make comparisons to Vélazquez. Fun fact-flautists can determine what note the boy is playing just by studying the painting closely.

values.name: perfect painting
values.artist: Paul Cézanne, circa 1899, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This still life is known to have inspired the work of many other artists, including Pablo Picasso. Rather than trying to recreate an image, Cézanne captured the beauty of shapes from many angles. With this work, Cézanne draws on both the atmosphere of his subjects and the spirit of its beholders.

values.name: proper painting
values.artist: Édouard Manet, circa 1882, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Close inspection of the mirror behind this painting's subject reveals many mysteries and paradoxes... In fact, the painting is based on multiple perspectives, which explains the unusual placement of some items. Sadly, this is Manet's last major work. He passed away a year after it was complete, at age 51.

values.name: quaint painting
values.artist: Johannes Vermeer, circa 1658, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This piece earned Vermeer the nickname "Master of Light" thanks to its exquisite contrast and depth. Vermeer painted this masterpiece at only 25 years of age. Many note that it is surprisingly small in real life.

values.name: quaint painting
values.artist: Johannes Vermeer, circa 1658, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This piece earned Vermeer the nickname "Master of Light" thanks to its exquisite contrast and depth. Vermeer painted this masterpiece at only 25 years of age. Many note that it is surprisingly small in real life.

values.name: robust statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 2nd century CE, Marble
values.museumDescription: This ancient Roman statue is based on the ancient Greek statue crafted by Myron. It's a piece that shows the grandeur of the human body, beautiful from any angle.

values.name: robust statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 2nd century CE, Marble
values.museumDescription: This ancient Roman statue is based on the ancient Greek statue crafted by Myron. It's a piece that shows the grandeur of the human body, beautiful from any angle.

values.name: rock-head statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 1000 BCE, Basalt, andesite
values.museumDescription: Giant stone head thought to be from the ancient Mesoamerican Olmec civilization. The larger ones can reach three meters in height. Scholars think they only crafted heads, no bodies.

values.name: rock-head statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 1000 BCE, Basalt, andesite
values.museumDescription: Giant stone head thought to be from the ancient Mesoamerican Olmec civilization. The larger ones can reach three meters in height. Scholars think they only crafted heads, no bodies.

values.name: scary painting
values.realArtworkTitle: Ōtani Oniji the 3rd as Yakko Edobei
values.artist: Tōshūsai Sharaku, 1794, Woodblock print
values.museumDescription: A print from the mid-Edo period by Tōshūsai Sharaku depicting a famous actor of the time. Sharaku made roughly 140 ukiyo-e prints in his career, even though it only spanned around 10 months!

values.name: scary painting
values.realArtworkTitle: Ōtani Oniji the 3rd as Yakko Edobei
values.artist: Tōshūsai Sharaku, 1794, Woodblock print
values.museumDescription: A print from the mid-Edo period by Tōshūsai Sharaku depicting a famous actor of the time. Sharaku made roughly 140 ukiyo-e prints in his career, even though it only spanned around 10 months!

values.name: scenic painting
values.artist: Pieter Brueghel the Elder, 1565, Oil on wood panel
values.museumDescription: A landscape artist from the late Renaissance period, Brueghel was known as the "Peasant Artist." He earned the title for depicting scenes from common peasant life, such as the moment captured here. Note the contrast between the weary hunters and the people frolicking below on icy ponds.

values.name: scenic painting
values.artist: Pieter Brueghel the Elder, 1565, Oil on wood panel
values.museumDescription: A landscape artist from the late Renaissance period, Brueghel was known as the "Peasant Artist." He earned the title for depicting scenes from common peasant life, such as the moment captured here. Note the contrast between the weary hunters and the people frolicking below on icy ponds.

values.name: serene painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1490, Oil on wood panel
values.museumDescription: One of only four portraits of women painted by da Vinci, one of which is the "Mona Lisa. "Some believe that the "ermine" is not actually an ermine, but rather a white ferret!

values.name: serene painting
values.artist: Leonardo da Vinci, circa 1490, Oil on wood panel
values.museumDescription: One of only four portraits of women painted by da Vinci, one of which is the "Mona Lisa. "Some believe that the "ermine" is not actually an ermine, but rather a white ferret!

values.name: sinking painting
values.artist: John Everett Millais, 1852, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Ophelia is a tragic figure in the Shakespearean play "Hamlet." There is an otherworldly expression on her face as she lies unconscious in a river. She is surrounded by the beauty of nature as she floats between life and death.

values.name: solemn painting
values.artist: Diego Velázquez, circa 1656, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This famous piece by Velázquez, who served the Spanish court, shows us something about perspective. It depicts a young princess with her "ladies-in-waiting." The artist himself is seen to the left. The king and queen are reflected in the mirror to the artist's right, so the perspective is that of the king. The king...watching the artist...paint the king and the queen...

values.name: solemn painting
values.artist: Diego Velázquez, circa 1656, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: This famous piece by Velázquez, who served the Spanish court, shows us something about perspective. It depicts a young princess with her "ladies-in-waiting." The artist himself is seen to the left. The king and queen are reflected in the mirror to the artist's right, so the perspective is that of the king. The king...watching the artist...paint the king and the queen...

values.name: tremendous statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 1200 BCE, Bronze
values.museumDescription: This bronze ding from ancient China is the largest and heaviest ever found. The script on the inside suggests it was created to honor the king's mother.

values.name: tremendous statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 1200 BCE, Bronze
values.museumDescription: This bronze ding from ancient China is the largest and heaviest ever found. The script on the inside suggests it was created to honor the king's mother.

values.name: twinkling painting
values.artist: Vincent van Gogh, 1889, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Van Gogh's signature piece, painted while he was hospitalized at an asylum. This view from his room includes memories and imaginations. In letters to friends, the artist called it a failure.

values.name: valiant statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 190 BCE, Marble
values.museumDescription: A statue of the goddess of victory, Nike, found on Samothrace. It shows Nike alighting on the prow of a ship. Originally found in separate pieces, it has largely been restored, but the arms and head are still missing.

values.name: valiant statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, circa 190 BCE, Marble
values.museumDescription: A statue of the goddess of victory, Nike, found on Samothrace. It shows Nike alighting on the prow of a ship. Originally found in separate pieces, it has largely been restored, but the arms and head are still missing.

values.name: warm painting
values.artist: Francisco de Goya, circa 1805, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: It is said that this painting is a more discreet version of an earlier work known as "The Nude Maja." It is also known that Francisco de Goya was quite popular in his own time. Could these facts be related? A third, unrelated fact-the word "maja" refers to a "stylish young lady of Madrid."

values.name: warrior statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 210 BCE, Earthenware
values.museumDescription: These terracotta warriors were buried with the first Qin emperor to protect him in the afterlife. Nearly 2,000 years later, in 1974, about 8,000 of them were found. Each life-sized statue is said to have been handmade with different poses, expressions, and clothing.

values.name: warrior statue
values.artist: Artist Unknown, 210 BCE, Earthenware
values.museumDescription: These terracotta warriors were buried with the first Qin emperor to protect him in the afterlife. Nearly 2,000 years later, in 1974, about 8,000 of them were found. Each life-sized statue is said to have been handmade with different poses, expressions, and clothing.

values.name: wild painting left half
values.realArtworkTitle: Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin
values.artist: Tawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century, Gold leaf and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This folding screen shows dynamic brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on a gold-leaf background. It is thought to be the masterpiece of Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo- period artist. The simplification of the subjects is a style that was carried on by Ogata Kōrin. It's a style still in use today in the Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

values.name: wild painting left half
values.realArtworkTitle: Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin
values.artist: Tawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century, Gold leaf and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This folding screen shows dynamic brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on a gold-leaf background. It is thought to be the masterpiece of Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo- period artist. The simplification of the subjects is a style that was carried on by Ogata Kōrin. It's a style still in use today in the Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

values.name: wild painting right half
values.realArtworkTitle: Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin
values.artist: Tawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century, Gold leaf and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This folding screen shows dynamic brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on a gold-leaf background. It is thought to be the masterpiece of Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo- period artist. The simplification of the subjects is a style that was carried on by Ogata Kōrin. It's a style still in use today in the Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

values.name: wild painting right half
values.realArtworkTitle: Folding Screen of Fūjin and Raijin
values.artist: Tawaraya Sōtatsu, 17th century, Gold leaf and ink on paper
values.museumDescription: This folding screen shows dynamic brushwork of Fūjin and Raijin on a gold-leaf background. It is thought to be the masterpiece of Tawaraya Sōtatsu, an early-Edo- period artist. The simplification of the subjects is a style that was carried on by Ogata Kōrin. It's a style still in use today in the Rinpa school of Japanese painting.

values.name: wistful painting
values.artist: Johannes Vermeer, circa 1665, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Also known as "Girl with a Turban," this piece uses ultramarine paint, which was expensive at the time. It seems the expense was worth it, as the vivid blue colors draw the eye and help make the piece a classic. The only question is... Is that a real pearl earring? Or something else...

values.name: wistful painting
values.artist: Johannes Vermeer, circa 1665, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Also known as "Girl with a Turban," this piece uses ultramarine paint, which was expensive at the time. It seems the expense was worth it, as the vivid blue colors draw the eye and help make the piece a classic. The only question is... Is that a real pearl earring? Or something else...

values.name: worthy painting
values.artist: Eugène Delacroix, 1830, Oil on canvas
values.museumDescription: Painted by leading 19th century Romantic artist Delacroix in the same year as a French revolution. The woman in the center is often mistaken for Joan of Arc, but she is actually the fictional "Marianne."
